identified-content.object.title: CHRONICLE (TIMES COLUMN)
identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Media, Entertainment and Publishing

block.p: LOUIS AUCHINCLOSS , the author of books about the upper-crust world of the Social Register, is not too impressed that he has just published his 50th book.
"There is no great virtue in quantity," he said the other day. "I remind myself that Emily Bronte wrote a single novel -- and then she died at 29."
LOUIS AUCHINCLOSS , the author of books about the upper-crust world of the Social Register, is not too impressed that he has just published his 50th book.
"There is no great virtue in quantity," he said the other day. "I remind myself that Emily Bronte wrote a single novel -- and then she died at 29."

Tomorrow evening, Houghton Mifflin, the publisher of 41 of his 50 works, is giving him a dinner at its headquarters in Boston to celebrate "The Collected Stories of Louis Auchincloss" and the milestone it signifies.

Many pieces in the anthology, written from 1949 to 1994, include "a lot of stories which were moldering in out-of-print editions," he said. "I went through all my books and selected the ones I thought were best. They simply jumped out at me."

Mr. Auchincoloss, 77, retired from the practice of law in 1987 and is now teaching literature courses at New York University. And then there is book No. 51: "I've just submitted my new novel, called "The Education of Oscar Fairfax," he said. NADINE BROZAN
